html:
Alternative forms[edit]

  • vadiō, guadiō, gagiō, gajō, gaviō, wadicō

Etymology[edit]

From wadium (“a contract”).

Verb[edit]

wadiō (present infinitive wadiāre, perfect active wadiāvī, supine wadiātum); first conjugation[1][2]

  1. (Medieval Latin) I contract
  2. (Medieval Latin) I guarantee
  3. (Medieval Latin) I pay a fine
  4. (Medieval Latin) I mortgage
  5. (Medieval Latin) I take hostage

Conjugation[edit]

Descendants[edit]

  • Old French: gager, gagier, guagier
    • Middle French: guagier, gager
      • French: gager
    • → Middle English: gagen
      • English: gage
    • Old French: gageure
      • French: gageure, gageüre
  • Old Northern French: wagier
    • → Middle English: wagen
      • English: wage
    • Old Northern French: wageure, wagour
      • → Middle English: wager, waiour, wageour, waiowre, wagour
        • English: wager

References[edit]

  1. ^ Niermeyer, Jan Frederik (1976), “wadiare”, in Mediae Latinitatis Lexicon Minus, Leiden, Boston: Brill, page 1119
  2. ^ wadiare in Charles du Fresne du Cange’s Glossarium Mediæ et Infimæ Latinitatis (augmented edition, 1883–1887)
